awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Java Colonial Encounters
awd_abstract_narration:
Food is a biological necessity, but it also assumes important dynamic social functions and cultural symbolic values. To understand the nature of interaction among early cultures, the analysis of archaeologically recovered food remains can reveal important insights into social relationships, power negotiations, and cultural adaptation that complement - and sometimes correct - the often biased and incomplete historical records. The use of food in power negotiations and boundary making can be especially enlightening when examining cultural interaction in colonial settings, where a complex array of political, economic, and social differences must be untangled. 

In this project, Ms. Kaoru Ueda of Boston University (BU), under the guidance of Dr. Robert Murowchick, will conduct archaeological excavations and analysis of food and food-related remains from one of history's most important colonial encounters, that of the Dutch East India Company (or VOC) in Southeast Asia during the 17th and 18th centuries. As a powerful economic engine, the VOC greatly impacted European international relationships and global empire-building efforts. Importantly, it also left a legacy of colonial and post-colonial politics that still resonates today in one of the most culturally diverse and economically important regions of Asia. 

This project will focus on the powerful Islamic sultanate located at Banten, Java, Indonesia, and the key Dutch forts and trading centers that were built there to establish and maintain VOC control over this highly lucrative spice trade. Because of the subjectivity of existing historical records, the nature of the cross-cultural interaction between these local elites and the Dutch at Banten has been poorly understood. The archaeological research of sites at Banten will provide an objective and revealing tool with which to evaluate Indonesian-European cultural interactions in this early phase of global trade. Banten is an important and unique colonial case study, different from the Americas, because Europeans were only one of many foreign merchant groups in this prominent cosmopolitan city at the beginning of their encounter. This new data will advance our understanding of early colonialism around the world.

The proposed research will have a broad impact beyond its specific research topics. The project will foster collaborative research and training among Indonesian, Singaporean, and American archaeologists and students in one of the most archaeologically under-studied regions of the world.  It will improve the practice of historical archaeology in Indonesia by introducing young local archaeologists to new analytical techniques, such as the study of plant silica remains from archaeological soil samples to better understand past diets (a method particularly useful in the tropics, where ancient organic remains rarely survive). These new materials will improve the collections of BU's Environmental Archaeology Laboratory and provide analytical training to BU's undergraduate and graduate students.

The project focuses on the evolving relationship between Muslim and European societies in the early modern world, a relationship of obvious importance today. The results of fieldwork at Banten, one of Indonesia's most revered Islamic sites in the world's most populous Muslim-majority country, will be made available to the public through publication in refereed journals, presentations at academic conferences in the US and abroad, and in bilingual exhibitions in Banten's local on-site museum. The results of this research are already fostering international scholarly exchanges in the U.S., Indonesia, Singapore, Taiwan, and Japan through presentation of conference papers, as well as increasing public awareness of early colonial history in this spice trading center through Massachusetts Archaeology Month events each October.

Intellectual Merit: The results of this research at Banten are contributing to our growing recognition and understanding of the diversity of colonial encounters around the world, and the complexity and multi-directionality of cross-cultural interactions even in the early stages of colonialism. This project has underscored the importance of going beyond the typical models that seek to explain the adoption and mixing of material culture in colonial situations. Unlike many other widely studied colonial encounters, the trading port of Banten already had a long history of cross-cultural interaction. By the time the Dutch arrived in Banten in 1596, they were only one of many groups of foreign merchants in this prominent cosmopolitan city. An important contribution of this project, therefore, is that this Banten case study offers a significant opportunity to examine how cultures are influenced and transformed in Dutch-Bantenese “colonial” encounters and to place them beyond the narrow traditional framework of European colonizers and indigenous colonized.

These research results, combined with other archaeological data analyses performed by regional specialists, from three contemporaneous sites within the same archaeological complex at Banten permitted us to make cross-cultural comparisons in multi-faceted ways. Our comprehensive archaeological analyses represent an inaugural application of archaeological science in the field of historical archaeology in Indonesia. The paleoethnobotanical research of economic plants allowed us to broaden the breadth of the archaeological record, augmenting our understanding of this understudied region and helping to guide the direction of future research design. Petrographic analyses of earthenware helped differentiate local products from imports, allowing for the examination of foreign cultural influence on all types of food vessels beyond the widely studied Chinese and European ceramics and shifting the focus of cultural influence within the island of Java.

 

Broader Impact: The research is more broadly significant in at least five ways. First, the funding supported the completion of a doctoral dissertation by Kaoru Ueda, a female archaeologist of Japanese origin who has recently immigrated to the U.S. Second, this research focused on Southeast Asia, one of the most archaeologically under-studied regions of the world, helping to bring this critical area to the table of world archaeological discourse. Third, the study focused on the relationship between Muslim and European societies in the early modern world, a relationship that is increasingly important to understand both globally and in Indonesia, the largest Muslim nation in the world. Fourth, the bilingual museum brochures that provide project results in English and Indonesian have the potential to reach a wide scholarly, public, and governmental audience, contributing to a more balanced and inclusive understanding of Indonesian and Southeast Asian maritime history. Fifth, Ueda’s active participation in international conferences and workshops in the United States and Asia and her future publications are expected to help disseminate the research results to stimulate discussion of colonialism from a global perspective.

This approach to the study of colonialism, which combines theoretically driven scientific archaeology with the study of historical documents, has rarely been conducted in Indonesia. The fieldwork, therefore, offered unique opportunities to train young local Indonesian archaeologists in current archaeological and analytical methods. A pilot archaeological field school began in 2011 to facilitate this training, and the research results and techniques have been presented in the local archaeological office in Serang, Province of Banten.
